item.title: Mama'titinas Diksion친rion Chamoru
item.description: H친fa adai todus hamyu guennao huyung ni' tumataitai esti! It’s been over a month-and-a-half since I’ve blogged and not a week has gone by where I thought to myself, “ai adai, debi di bai fa’tinas otru na blog”, but honestly my schedule has just been todu machalapon.
item.content:encoded:
H친fa adai todus hamyu guennao huyung ni' tumataitai esti!

It’s been over a month-and-a-half since I’ve blogged and not a week has gone by where I thought to myself, “ai adai, debi di bai fa’tinas otru na blog”, but honestly my schedule has just been todu machalapon. I had to take a step back from dang near everything and reasses my priorities and how I spend my time outside of work - hence my absence 游땐.

BUT it was much needed as I’m here now and ready to share a bit about what I’ve been working on, which is: a personal Chamoru dictionary stored on my computer. This project was born out of three “issues” I kept running into:

  1. My favorite go-to resource for looking up Chamoru words (LearningChamoru.com) required too many steps*
  2. There were a lot of words I couldn’t find when searching
  3. Number 1 seems to only reflect the Guam Orthography, and I wanted something “more complete” (i.e., something with words spelled using the CNMI orthography)

* Too many steps = opening a browser, clicking login, logging in, scrolling down to “Dictionary”, and then searching for a word.

Pues, hu tutuhun i hinanao-hu. I created a template of what I thought a dictionary would look like on the back-end (in a database) and I started gathering as many words as I could find. Anytime I came across a new word, I’d pop open my database and add it in there. It took an egregious amount of time but I finally got to a place where I felt comfortable enough to start working on a “front-end” to access the database. I put that in quotes because in it’s current state I can only access it from a terminal/command-line interface (CLI). I started it off this way sa' gi minag친het, it’s where I live when I code. Also it’s the fastest way I can access the database. Essentially I created a small program that allows me to access it via the CLI.

Here’s a screenshot of me running the program:

If you’re unfamiliar with what you’re looking at, it’s a terminal/CLI. The points of interest are the second line, where you see 較덕 $ sodda, and then the text afterwards. My program runs when I type sodda and hit enter. I get prompted for a word to search for (in this case I entered " tungo' “), and then if it finds something I get results back. Otherwise it says it can’t find the word and the prompts just continue until I exit.

Cleaning the data and structuring how everything is stored/returned actually took the most amount of time. I wrote a lot of small helper programs to do things like sort the words, remove misformed words, and add new words, but I still have a lot of work ahead of me. There are still ~3000 words I have that I need to add but don’t have exact translations for. There are also a bunch of words I just straight up don’t have either.

To give you a sense of how big this dictionary has gotten, here is where I’m at:

Currently I store everything in a JSON file, where each word will take up roughly ~20-25 lines. This is near the bottom of the file and as you can see it’s around 340,000 lines (last I checked, there were ~17,000 words). Some functionality is still missing like a) being able to give an English word and get a Chamoru word back, and b) giving suggestions/alternative spellings to what you provided.

Hinasso-ku na sen pairi esti!…lao…there’s one potential problem. I haven’t put this out there yet for everyone to see and try because I actually don’t know if I legally can 游뱂.

I haven’t mentioned this yet, and perhaps you were able to pick it up from earlier when I mentioned why I created this tool, but…I didn’t create a majority of this information from scratch. I made use of LearningChamoru.com, news articles from the GuamPDN, and any blog I could find that seemed like a great resource for filling up a dictionary. So for example, let’s say you use this tool and look up the word “magof” - one of the definitions you’d get back is the same one you’d find in LearningChamoru.com, word-for-word.

Pues hunggan, as much as I want to share this right now, there are still some things I need to figure out. Things like: if I put this dictionary out there, say on a website, would I receive a cease & desist? Could I get sued for copyright infringement? Would I be fine so long as I attribute my data to their correct creators? Etc…

Now that I think about it though…the front-end stuff I can probably share. You’d of course need a dictionary stored in a same-structured JSON, but that general structure I can also share. But for now, this is all I’ll share. When I get more answers and more data and create something more accessible, I’ll give another update!

Todu ha' para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.
item.dc:creator: David Taitingfong

item.title: Mama'titinas Trongkun Mangg친fa
item.description: I’ve been on a journey to document my family tree in a tech-saavy way. It started off simple: try and find out who my great-grandparents were.
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been on a journey to document my family tree in a tech-saavy way. It started off simple: try and find out who my great-grandparents were. I honestly didn’t think I’d get past that because before this I couldn’t even tell you the names of any of my great-grandparents. But as you’ll soon find out, my simple task turned into a research-heavy adventure which is still ongoing.

This wasn’t on my to-do list until recently - I’d say within the last 2 years. I never really thought about any family past my grandparents; I never wondered who their parents or grandparents were. I also gave little thought to who their siblings were. I mean, growing up it just wasn’t something that they talked about. I want to say that I didn’t even know if they had had any siblings, although that became apparent closer to when I was in high school and started meeting extended family. It wouldn’t be until the passing of my grandmas that I would start to pay more attention. And it wouldn’t be until just about 2 years ago that I would start digging into my family history.

| Note: I’ll refer to my grandparents as Grandma/Grandpa A and Grandma/Grandpa T; Aquiningoc and Taitingfong respectively.

Gathering Documents

The first event that really triggered my search was receiving documents about my mom’s side of the family. My aunt had been holding onto them from when she was cleaning house, and I guess she just never thought that it would be of any excitement to us. I recall asking about family names - clan names in particular - and she went to her room to retrieve all the stuff she had. When she came back I was astounded: she had birth certificates, death certificates, legal documents, obituaries, funeral pamphlets, social security cards, and a lot more. The documents that piqued my interest were the ones about my grandma A’s siblings and some homemade lineage documents for my grandpa A’s side. I saw “Aquiningoc” on that paper but none of the names looked remotely familiar.

Later that week I asked my dad what he knew about his parents. He told me not much but that he would ask his siblings what they knew. Within a few hours my dad had text me some scans: a photo of my grandpa T’s mom, a photo of my grandma T and her grandma, and a homemade lineage document detailing my grandma T’s family.

The two lineage documents were incredible finds. The one for my grandma T started with her grandparents. It listed their kids and all the grandchildren. My grandma was one of those grandchildren. Success: I found a set of great-grandparents!

The one for my grandpa A was even more interesting. It was laid out in a similar fashion: grandparents at the top, children below, and grandchildren below that. But my grandpa wasn’t on this list…his dad wasn’t even on the list. I would come to find out that it was my grandpa A’s grandpa listed…as a grandchild! So not only did I find another set of great-grandparents, but a set of their great-grandparents.

I was so amazed yet at the same time a bit sad. These were people I never learned about and, gi minag친het, likely never will. I made a decision right there to document everything I could; to create something that I can pass down to my children and to my siblings and cousins and aunts and todu i manggaf친-hu.

I started writing down names on paper but that got out of hand quickly. Thus started my search for a tool I could easily use and (hopefully) easily share.

Finding the Right Tool

They say the best time to start something was yesterday; the next best time is right now. With that in mind I figured I’d start with a spreadsheet-like program, so I started working in Google Sheets. It started off easy because I had only noted down my immediate family and my grandparents from both sides. When it came to writing down my uncles and aunts though I started to realize that wow: this is going to get out of hand quickly; my dad is 1 of 10, my mom is 1 of 6…I don’t know about my grandparents, but I knew from the documents I had that their families were also “big”.

While continuing to work in Google Sheets I started to also look for alternatives because what started as a 3 sheet file grew into 16 sheets…and that was just going up my family tree, i.e., I was only tracing parents and their parents and their parents and etc. I was able to track i ma침ain친-hu back 6 generations. Things started getting complicated and I needed a new tool.

I temporarily used MyHeritage because it was convenient & had a decent amount of data I could use. There also were people there that had connections to some of my great- and great-great-grandparents, and to be honest that was pretty cool. But MyHeritage had it’s limitations: the desktop app was great, but it felt like most of the magic was happening on the web-side; also, most of the data that I needed to fill in the gaps in my tree were behind paywalls.

Sidebar: I much prefer desktop apps as opposed to web apps. From a business perspective, I understand why web apps are more ubiquitous…but I tend to opt for desktop.

I paused on entering new data and went to search for a different tool. That’s when I came across Gramps, an open-source genealogical research software - it’s essentially a database (DB) with a decent GUI. This felt right up my alley: 1) it’s a desktop app, 2) it’s open-source, and 3) it’s written in my favorite coding language! Okay, I’m getting off track but the point is: I found the right tool.

Once I got the app installed, I probably spent a straight 12 hours just entering information and getting things to a presentable state.

Finding External Sources

I spent a few days on-and-off going between my documents and my DB, but it came to a point where I felt like I’d exhausted all internal sources. I kept trying to climb up my family tree but I eventually hit the canopy, so to speak. I had gained so much momentum and made so much progress that I didn’t want to it stop…but it did. I hit a wall for a few weeks and accepted that I would just continue when something came my way. I stopped working on my tree for about 2 months until I had this urge to revisit my sources, and I’m so glad I did. My next big leaps came in two parts.

Part 1: stumbling upon the incredible work of Si침ot Bernard Punzalan, particularly a PDF he created which contains Chamoru clan names. It was from this PDF that I was able to confirm some clan names that my parents had told me about. I figured, hey: I can probably find more info if I not only searched by my family names but my clan names as well, which ultimately led me to part two.

Part 2: finding a set of great-grandparents for my grandma A via a blog written by P친le' Eric. It was around this moment that I realized just how much info P친le' Eric had on his blog. After spending more time reading on his site, I came across another blog which helped me (very likely) confirm my ancestry back 9 generations! Honestly though, I wouldn’t have second-guessed this blog if I hadn’t already spent some time in MyHeritage, because it was there that I discovered more people from my Aquiningoc/Taitano side.

I have a feeling I’ll be able to get more info later on when I’m able to sub to Si침ot Bernard’s Chamorro Roots Database, but for the time being I’ve slowed down on the tree.

My Tree Right Now

As of today, this is what my “family tree” (in fan-form) looks like right now.

My dad’s side:

My mom’s side:

As you can see, I was able to at least get all of my great-grandparents. I’m still missing a few great-great-grandparents, and honestly from there it’s scrambled. Truth be told, I’m incredibly surprised I was able to get as much info as I have! For now I think I’m going to focus on my uncles, aunts, and cousins. I’m hoping to be able to create something that I can share at big family gatherings. I also plan on doing my wife’s side. Gi minag친het, this is fun and relaxing for me.

I think this seals it - I’m our self-proclaimed Family Historian 游땙.

Todu ha' para p친’gu. Bula guinaiya! — DJT.

Extra info:

  • Gramps GitHub page
  • Other papers by Si침ot Bernard Punzalan
item.dc:creator: David Taitingfong
